good

N. Y. World
11 February, 1926
For Miss Carter:
div1.p: THE WORLD: THURSD
It Seems to Me
By Heywood Broun

The papers announced yesterday that Gen. Pershing
would go to Walter Reed Hospital. Of course, I am
familiar with the institution, as it has been mentioned
often in the news, but now I make a new association
with the name, for I have read the chapter on yellow
fever in Paul de Kruif's “Microbe Hunters.” Until
then I knew nothing of this Walter Reed. Possibly
my ignorance was personal and it may be that most
other people know the story of his campaign. Still, I
think that few would recognize the name Jesse
Lazear, although a battery has been named for him
in Baltimore Harbor, and I am even more certain
that Kissinger is quite forgotton.

And this is unfortunate, for these men engaged in
an offensive as romantic as any tale of the wars of
America. When a Chicago educator recently declared
that the school histories devoted too much space to
military exploits he was roundly denounced as one
intent upon diminishing patriotism. But from any
point of view a case may well be made that the con-
quest of yellow fever was of greater importance than
San Juan Hill or any of the other Cuban skirmishes.
It lasted less in memory. Kissinger, who distinguished
himself so conspicuously in a major medical engage-
ment, is not only forgotten by such casual readers
as myself but by the Government as well. He was
among the first to volunteer to take a bite in the
interest of science, and de Kruif reports:

“He didn't die from yellow fever. And they pre-
vailed upon him at last to accept $115 and a gold
watch, which was presented to him in the presence
of the officers and men of Columbia Barracks. He
didn't die--but, what was worse, as the yellow fever
germs went out of him a paralysis crept into him, and
now he sits counting the hours on his gold watch.
But what luck! At the last account he had a good
wife to support him by taking in washing.”

It would be interesting, I think, for some newspaper
to check up on this last account and ascertain how
Kissinger fares. So far has he fallen out of popular
attention that even de Kruif, his chronicler, seems
not to know the first name of his hero, but calls him
only “Private Kissinger of Ohio.”

It is probably true that the paralysis of Kissinger
had nothing to do with the yellow fever which he
ontracted for the sake of humanity. And again, in
justification of the Government, both Kissinger and
his companion, John J. Moran, civilian clerk, were
warned of the dangers which they would undergo in
allowing themselves to be bitten by fever-laden mos-
quitoes, and, besides, all this happened quite a while
ago. Yellow fever was bad in Havana in 1900, and
Major Walter Reed came to Quemados. in Cuba, with
orders “to give special attention to questions relating
to the cause and prevention of yellow fever.” Major
Reed never took a bite himself, but that was his
plan, and only the insistence of his subordinates pre-
vented him. Capt. James Carroll was one of the
“guinea-pigs” who recovered and, after his death
seven years later, Congress voted his wife a pension
of $1,500, and the same annuity goes to the widow of
Walter Reed and to Mrs. Lazear, whose husband did
die of the fever.

Jernegan and Folk, privates, took what seemed at
the time a fearful risk, though later it proved safe
enough. But that they did not know when they spent
a night wrapped in the blankets of yellow fever vic-
tims. Jernegan and Folk were way up at the head of
the column, and in those days science was back in the
rear scrambling to catch up. De Kruif seems to have
no information as to what happened to either of these
men in later life, but anyway they received $300
apiece when they undertook the experiment.

Early in his investigation Walter Reed made up his
mind that yellow fever was carried by mosquitoes, but,
of course, there was no way of proving that without
experiment. Animal experimentation might serve to
bolster the theory, but the army's concern was with
men, and things that are true of animals don't always
work out with human beings. De Kruif begins his
tale of the episode as follows:

“So, on one hot night after a day among the dying
men at Pinar del Rio, he faced his commission: ‘If
the members of the commission take the risk first--
if they let themselves be bitten by mosquitoes that
have fed on yellow fever cases--that will set an ex-
ample to American soldiers, and then’--- Reed looked
at Lazear and then at James Carroll.

"‘I am ready to take a bite,’ said Jesse Lazear,
who had a wife and two small children.

"‘You can count on me, sir,’ said James Carroll,
whose total assets were his searcher's brain and his
miserable pay as an assistant surgeon in the army.
(His liabilities were a wife and five children).

Lazear and seven nameless ones were first to make
the test and none of them took sick. James Carroll
was the next. "He told Lazear to bring out the most
dangerous mosquito in his collection--not one that had
bitten only a single case, but he must use a mosquito
that had bitten many cases--and they must be bad
cases--of yellow fever. That mosquito must be as
dangerous as possible. On the 27th of August Jesse
Lazear picked out what he thought to be his champion
mosquito, and this creature, which had fed on four
cases of yellow fever, two of them severe ones, set-
tled down on the arm of James Carroll.

"That soldier watched her while she felt around
with her stinger. . . . What did he think as he
watched her swell into a bright balloon with his
blood? Nobody knows. But he could think what
everybody knows: ‘I am forty-six years old and in
yellow fever the older the fewer--get better.’ He
was forty-six years old. He had a wife and five chil-
dren, but that evening James Carroll wrote to Walter
Reed:

“‘If there is anything in the mosquito theory, I
should get a good dose of yellow fever.’ He did.”

Carroll was very ill but recovered, and later William
Dean of Grand Rapids, Mich., took a bite and got
the fever. But there was a flaw in these experiments.
Both Carroll and Dean had moved about freely and
their fever might have been contracted from some
other source and not from the bite of the mosquito.
Kissinger and Moran volunteered when a call was
issued for men to meet the experiment and follow it
up by living under quarantine conditions, “which
would make them first class, unquestionable guinea-
pigs, above suspicion and beyond reproach.”

I have just an edge of suspicion that de Kruif has
romanticized the scene a little in the telling, but that
is excusable, for certainly all the materials of melo-
drama are present.

"Then Walter Reed told them of the generosity of
Gen. Wood. A handsome sum of money they would
get--two hundred, maybe three hundred dollars, if the
silver-striped she-mosquitoes did things to them that
would give them one chance out of five not to spend
the money.

"‘The one condition on which we volunteer, sir,’
said Private Kissinger and Civilian Clerk John J.
Moran of Ohio, ‘is that we get no compensation for it.’

“To the tip of his cap went the hand of Walter Reed
(who was a Major): ‘Gentlemen, I salute you.’”

And so I would like to know how things go now
with Moran and Kissinger.
